context: During this era of Porfirian rule, the city underwent an extensive modernization. <a1_0>Many Spanish Colonial style buildings were destroyed<a1_0/>, replaced by new much larger Porfirian institutions and many outlying rural zones were transformed into urban or industrialized districts with most having electrical, gas and sewage utilities <a0_0>by 1908<a0_0/>. While the initial focus was on developing modern <a2_0>hospitals, schools, factories and massive public works<a2_0/>, perhaps the most long-lasting effects of the Porfirian modernization were creation of the Colonia Roma area and the development of <a3_0>Reforma Avenue<a3_0/>. Many of Mexico City's major attractions and landmarks were built during this era in this style.
